expanded_description: Why do some things cost more than others? Why are concert tickets sometimes impossible to get, while other events have plenty of empty seats? The answer lies in the interaction of two powerful forces: supply and demand. These twin concepts are the foundation of microeconomics, explaining how prices are determined and how markets allocate resources. When you understand supply and demand, you understand why gasoline prices rise in the summer, why rent is higher in cities, and why new technology gets cheaper over time. In this unit, we'll explore the laws of supply and demand, how they interact to determine market prices and quantities, what happens when markets are out of balance, and how changes in underlying conditions shift the curves and create new equilibria.

core_concept.principle: Supply and demand are the forces that make market economies work. They determine the quantity of each good produced and the price at which it is sold. (1) Demand: The relationship between price and quantity demanded by consumers. The law of demand states that, ceteris paribus, as price increases, quantity demanded decreases—an inverse relationship. This is shown by a downward-sloping demand curve. (2) Supply: The relationship between price and quantity supplied by producers. The law of supply states that, ceteris paribus, as price increases, quantity supplied increases—a direct relationship. This is shown by an upward-sloping supply curve. (3) Market equilibrium: The point where supply and demand curves intersect, determining the market-clearing price and quantity. At this price, the quantity consumers want to buy exactly equals the quantity producers want to sell. (4) Disequilibrium: When price is above equilibrium, quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded, creating a surplus. When price is below equilibrium, quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied, creating a shortage. Market forces push prices toward equilibrium. (5) Shifts vs. movements: Changes in price cause movements along curves. Changes in other factors (income, input prices, technology, etc.) cause the entire curves to shift, creating new equilibria.
core_concept.explanation: Think of supply and demand like a dance. Consumers want low prices; producers want high prices. The market price is where they meet—the compromise that clears the market. If price is too high, too many sellers want to dance but few buyers show up (surplus). If price is too low, too many buyers want to dance but few sellers appear (shortage). The price adjusts until the number of willing buyers equals the number of willing sellers—the market equilibrium.

sections.introduction: Why do people buy more strawberries when they're in season and cheap, and fewer when they're expensive? This everyday observation reflects the law of demand: when price goes up, quantity demanded goes down, and vice versa. But demand is more than just a simple relationship—it reflects consumer preferences, income, and the prices of related goods. In this section, we'll explore the law of demand, what shapes demand curves, the difference between demand and quantity demanded, and the factors that can cause demand to shift.

key_concept.definition: Demand refers to the entire relationship between price and quantity demanded, while quantity demanded is the specific amount consumers are willing to buy at a particular price. The law of demand states that, ceteris paribus (all else equal), there is an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded. This occurs for two reasons: (1) Substitution effect: As price rises, consumers substitute toward relatively cheaper alternatives. (2) Income effect: As price rises, consumers' real income falls, reducing purchasing power and quantity demanded. The demand curve graphs this relationship with price on the vertical axis and quantity on the horizontal axis. It slopes downward. A change in price causes a movement along the demand curve—a change in quantity demanded. A change in any other factor affecting demand causes the entire curve to shift—a change in demand. Key shifters (determinants of demand) include: (a) Income: For normal goods, demand increases when income rises; for inferior goods, demand decreases when income rises. (b) Prices of related goods: For substitutes (goods used in place of each other), a price increase in one increases demand for the other. For complements (goods used together), a price increase in one decreases demand for the other. (c) Tastes and preferences: Changes in consumer preferences shift demand. (d) Expectations: Expectations of future prices or income can shift current demand. (e) Number of buyers: More buyers increases demand.
key_concept.context: The concept of demand has been understood for centuries, but Alfred Marshall formalized it in his 1890 book 'Principles of Economics,' introducing the supply and demand diagram still used today. The law of demand is one of the most robust empirical regularities in economics—it holds across virtually all goods and contexts. Understanding demand is essential for analyzing consumer behavior, pricing decisions, and the effects of taxes, subsidies, and regulations.

classifications.value: Goods for which demand increases as income increases
classifications.behavior: Normal goods are what most people think of as typical goods: when consumers have more income, they buy more of them. This includes everything from restaurant meals to new cars to clothing. Normal goods can be further divided into necessities (goods we buy regardless of income, but buy slightly more as income rises—like basic food) and luxuries (goods we buy disproportionately more as income rises—like high-end electronics or vacations). For normal goods, the demand curve shifts to the right when income increases (more demanded at every price) and to the left when income decreases. The strength of the response depends on whether the good is a necessity or luxury.

image.alt: Graph showing demand curve shifting right as income increases
image.caption: Figure 2.1.3: Normal goods see increased demand when income rises.

examples.explanation: When people get raises, they tend to eat out more often. Demand for restaurant meals increases with income—a normal good.
As incomes rise, more households can afford new cars, increasing demand. During recessions (income falls), new car demand drops.

classifications.value: Goods for which demand decreases as income increases
classifications.behavior: Inferior goods are goods that consumers buy less of as their income rises. This doesn't mean the goods are low quality in an absolute sense—they're goods that people replace with better alternatives when they can afford to. Examples include generic brands, public transportation, and instant noodles. When a consumer's income increases, they might switch from generic cereal to name-brand, from bus to car, or from instant noodles to restaurant meals. For inferior goods, the demand curve shifts to the left when income increases (less demanded at every price) and to the right when income decreases. The term 'inferior' is an economic classification, not a value judgment—it simply describes how demand responds to income changes.

image.alt: Graph showing demand curve shifting left as income increases
image.caption: Figure 2.1.4: Inferior goods see decreased demand when income rises.

examples.explanation: A budget-conscious consumer buys generic corn flakes. After a promotion and raise, they switch to a name brand. Demand for generic cereal falls as income rises—it's an inferior good.
Low-income workers rely on buses. As their incomes rise, many buy cars and use transit less. Public transit ridership often declines in prosperous times (inferior) and increases in recessions.

classifications.behavior: Substitutes are goods that can be used in place of each other. When the price of one good rises, consumers switch to the substitute, increasing demand for the substitute. For example, if the price of coffee rises significantly, some consumers will switch to tea, increasing the demand for tea. Graphically, an increase in the price of a substitute shifts the demand curve for the original good to the right. A decrease in the price of a substitute shifts demand to the left. The cross-price elasticity of demand (responsiveness of demand for one good to price changes in another) is positive for substitutes. The closer the substitutes, the stronger the effect.

When butter prices spike, bakers and households switch to margarine, increasing margarine demand. They're close substitutes.

classifications.behavior: Complements are goods that are typically used together. When the price of one good rises, the demand for its complement falls because the combined cost of using both increases. For example, if the price of printers rises significantly, fewer people buy printers, which reduces the demand for printer ink (even if ink prices haven't changed). Graphically, an increase in the price of a complement shifts the demand curve for the original good to the left. A decrease in the price of a complement shifts demand to the right. The cross-price elasticity of demand is negative for complements. The stronger the complementary relationship, the larger the effect.

examples.explanation: If printer prices fall, more people buy printers, increasing demand for ink cartridges (complement). If printer prices rise, ink demand falls.
Higher gas prices increase the cost of driving, reducing demand for gas-guzzling vehicles. Cars and gasoline are complements.

principles.principle: Law of Demand: Inverse Price-Quantity Relationship
principles.statement: The law of demand states that, ceteris paribus, as the price of a good increases, the quantity demanded decreases, and as price decreases, quantity demanded increases. This inverse relationship is one of the most robust findings in economics. It holds because: (1) Substitution effect: Higher price makes other goods relatively cheaper, leading consumers to substitute away. (2) Income effect: Higher price reduces purchasing power, effectively lowering real income and reducing quantity demanded. The law applies to virtually all goods, though the strength of the response varies (elasticity). Exceptions are rare (Giffen goods, Veblen goods) and mainly theoretical. Understanding this law is essential for predicting how consumers respond to price changes, taxes, and subsidies.
principles.application: When analyzing a price change, predict that quantity demanded will move in the opposite direction. For policy analysis, consider how taxes (which raise prices) will reduce consumption, and subsidies (which lower prices) will increase consumption.
principles.example: When a city imposes a congestion charge (price increase for driving in certain areas), the quantity of vehicles driven decreases. When a store has a sale (price decrease), quantity demanded increases.

image.alt: Downward-sloping demand curve with arrows showing inverse relationship
image.caption: Figure 2.1.7: The law of demand: price up, quantity demanded down.

principles.principle: Distinguish Between Change in Demand and Change in Quantity Demanded
principles.statement: A common confusion in economics is the difference between a change in demand and a change in quantity demanded. A change in quantity demanded is a movement along a fixed demand curve, caused ONLY by a change in the price of the good itself. A change in demand is a shift of the entire demand curve, caused by a change in any other factor affecting demand—income, prices of related goods, tastes, expectations, or number of buyers. When the curve shifts, consumers buy different amounts at every price. This distinction is crucial for correctly analyzing market changes. In graphs, movements along are shown as arrows following the curve; shifts are shown as the curve moving to a new position.
principles.application: When analyzing a market event, first identify whether price changed (causing movement) or something else changed (causing shift). For example, 'price of coffee increased' affects quantity demanded of coffee (movement). 'Income increased' affects demand for coffee (shift).
principles.example: If the price of pizza rises, we move along the pizza demand curve—quantity demanded falls. If consumer incomes rise and pizza is normal, the entire pizza demand curve shifts right—more demanded at every price.

image.alt: Two graphs: one showing movement along demand curve, one showing shift of entire curve
image.caption: Figure 2.1.8: Change in quantity demanded (movement) vs. change in demand (shift).

principles.principle: Demand Curves Slope Downward Due to Substitution and Income Effects
principles.statement: The downward slope of demand curves is explained by two complementary effects: (1) Substitution effect: When the price of a good rises, it becomes more expensive relative to other goods. Rational consumers substitute away from the now-more-expensive good toward relatively cheaper alternatives. For example, if the price of beef rises, consumers buy more chicken. This effect always leads consumers to buy less of a good when its price rises. (2) Income effect: When the price of a good rises, consumers' real income (purchasing power) falls because they must spend more to buy the same amount. With lower real income, they reduce consumption of normal goods (and may increase consumption of inferior goods, but the overall effect for normal goods is reduced consumption). For normal goods, both effects work in the same direction, reinforcing the law of demand. For inferior goods, the income effect works opposite, but the substitution effect dominates, so the law of demand still holds.
principles.application: Understanding these effects helps explain consumer behavior beyond simple price responses. It also explains why demand for different goods responds differently to price changes based on their share of budget and availability of substitutes.
principles.example: When gasoline prices spike, consumers substitute by carpooling or using public transit (substitution effect) and also have less real income to spend on other goods (income effect). Both reduce gasoline consumption.

For each event in the coffee market, identify whether it causes a change in demand (shift) or change in quantity demanded (movement):
a) The price of coffee increases by \$1 per pound.
b) Consumer incomes decrease due to a recession.
c) The price of tea decreases significantly.

Price of coffee itself changes (temporary sale). This causes movement along demand—change in quantity demanded.
Number of buyers increases. This shifts demand right.

worked_examples.problem:
For each scenario, determine whether demand increases, decreases, or is indeterminate, and identify the type of good:
a) Income rises by 10%. Good A consumption rises by 15%.
b) Income falls by 5%. Good B consumption falls by 2%.
c) Income rises by 20%. Good C consumption falls by 10%.
d) Income falls by 8%. Good D consumption rises by 5%.
e) Income doubles. Good E consumption stays the same.

step_by_step.explanation: Income rises, consumption rises more than proportionally (15% > 10%). This is a normal good, specifically a luxury. Demand increases.
Income falls, consumption falls less than proportionally (2% < 5%). This is a normal good, specifically a necessity. Demand decreases.
Income rises, consumption falls. This is an inferior good. Demand decreases (shifts left).
Income falls, consumption rises. This is an inferior good. Demand increases (shifts right).
Income doubles, consumption unchanged. This is unusual—income elasticity of zero. The good is neither normal nor inferior in this range.

sections.introduction: Why do farmers plant more corn when prices are high? Why do oil companies drill more when oil prices rise? These behaviors reflect the law of supply: when price increases, quantity supplied increases. Producers respond to higher prices by increasing production because it becomes more profitable. But supply is more complex than just this relationship—it depends on production costs, technology, and expectations. In this section, we'll explore the law of supply, what shapes supply curves, the difference between supply and quantity supplied, and the factors that shift supply.

introduction_image.alt: Factory production line speeding up as demand increases
introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.2.1: The law of supply captures how producers respond to price changes.

key_concept.definition: Supply refers to the entire relationship between price and quantity supplied, while quantity supplied is the specific amount producers are willing to sell at a particular price. The law of supply states that, ceteris paribus, there is a direct relationship between price and quantity supplied. As price increases, quantity supplied increases; as price decreases, quantity supplied decreases. This occurs because: (1) Higher prices increase revenue, making production more profitable, encouraging firms to produce more. (2) Higher prices allow firms to cover higher marginal costs of production (the law of diminishing returns means costs rise as output expands). (3) Higher prices attract new firms into the market. The supply curve graphs this relationship with price on the vertical axis and quantity on the horizontal axis. It slopes upward. A change in price causes a movement along the supply curve—a change in quantity supplied. A change in any other factor affecting supply causes the entire curve to shift—a change in supply. Key shifters (determinants of supply) include: (a) Input prices: Lower input prices reduce production costs, increasing supply (shift right). Higher input prices decrease supply (shift left). (b) Technology: Technological improvements reduce costs, increasing supply (shift right). (c) Expectations: Expectations of future prices affect current supply. If prices are expected to rise, firms may reduce current supply to sell more later (shift left). (d) Number of sellers: More sellers increase supply (shift right). (e) Taxes and subsidies: Taxes increase costs, decreasing supply (shift left). Subsidies decrease costs, increasing supply (shift right). (f) Natural conditions: Weather, disasters, and other natural factors affect supply, especially in agriculture.
key_concept.context: The law of supply was also formalized by Alfred Marshall alongside demand. It reflects the profit-maximizing behavior of firms. In the short run, supply curves slope upward because of diminishing returns—as firms increase output, marginal costs rise, requiring higher prices to justify additional production. In the long run, supply may be more elastic as firms can adjust capacity. Understanding supply is essential for analyzing production decisions, industry dynamics, and the effects of taxes, regulations, and technological change.

image.caption: Figure 2.2.2: The supply curve slopes upward, showing direct price-quantity relationship.

classifications.value: Changes in cost of factors of production affect supply
characteristics: Shift opposite direction of input price
classifications.behavior: Input prices are a major determinant of supply. When the cost of labor, materials, energy, or other inputs rises, production becomes more expensive at every output level, reducing profitability. Firms respond by producing less at any given price—the supply curve shifts left. Conversely, when input prices fall, production becomes cheaper, increasing profitability and shifting supply right. For example, if steel prices rise, automobile supply decreases (shift left). If wages fall, supply increases (shift right). The size of the shift depends on how important the input is in production and how easily firms can substitute away from it.

image.alt: Factory with input costs rising, supply curve shifting left
image.caption: Figure 2.2.3: Higher input prices decrease supply (shift left); lower input prices increase supply (shift right).

examples.explanation: Crude oil is the main input for gasoline. When oil prices rise, gasoline supply decreases (shift left) because it's more expensive to produce gasoline at any given price.
A higher minimum wage increases labor costs for restaurants, reducing the supply of restaurant meals (shift left) as some restaurants may close or reduce hours.

classifications.value: Improvements in production methods increase supply
classifications.behavior: Technological progress reduces production costs, allowing firms to produce more output with the same inputs or the same output with fewer inputs. This increases profitability and shifts the supply curve to the right—more is supplied at every price. Technology can take many forms: new machinery, better production processes, improved organization, or innovations that reduce waste. Technological change is a primary driver of economic growth and has dramatically increased supply in industries from agriculture to manufacturing to services. In the modern economy, rapid technological progress continuously shifts supply curves rightward, lowering prices and increasing quantities over time for many goods.

image.alt: Factory with new technology, supply curve shifting right
image.caption: Figure 2.2.4: Technological improvements increase supply (shift right).

examples.explanation: Advances in manufacturing have dramatically reduced the cost of producing solar panels. The supply curve for solar panels has shifted far right, lowering prices and increasing adoption.
Hydraulic fracturing technology made it profitable to extract oil and gas from previously inaccessible deposits. This shifted the supply of oil and gas rightward, lowering energy prices.

classifications.behavior: Government policies significantly affect supply. Taxes on production (per-unit taxes, excise taxes, or taxes on inputs) increase the cost of production, reducing profitability and shifting supply left. For example, a tax on cigarettes reduces the supply of cigarettes. Subsidies (government payments to producers) reduce production costs, increasing profitability and shifting supply right. For example, agricultural subsidies increase the supply of corn. Regulations can also affect supply: environmental regulations, safety standards, and licensing requirements may increase production costs, shifting supply left. Deregulation may reduce costs and shift supply right. Understanding these effects is crucial for analyzing the impact of government policy on markets.

image.alt: Tax icon causing left shift, subsidy icon causing right shift
image.caption: Figure 2.2.5: Taxes decrease supply (shift left); subsidies increase supply (shift right).

examples.explanation: A tax on sugary drinks increases production costs for beverage companies, shifting the supply curve for sugary drinks left (higher price, lower quantity).
Government subsidies for wind power reduce production costs for wind energy companies, shifting supply right and encouraging more renewable energy production.

principles.principle: Law of Supply: Direct Price-Quantity Relationship
principles.statement: The law of supply states that, ceteris paribus, as the price of a good increases, the quantity supplied increases, and as price decreases, quantity supplied decreases. This direct relationship holds because: (1) Higher prices increase revenue per unit, making production more profitable and encouraging firms to increase output. (2) Higher prices allow firms to cover the higher marginal costs that come from increasing production (due to diminishing returns). (3) In the long run, higher prices attract new firms into the industry, further increasing quantity supplied. The law applies to most goods and services, though the strength of the response varies (elasticity). Understanding this law is essential for predicting how producers respond to price changes, taxes, and market opportunities.
principles.application: When analyzing a price change, predict that quantity supplied will move in the same direction. For policy analysis, consider how subsidies (which effectively increase price received by producers) will increase supply, and taxes (which reduce net price) will decrease supply.
principles.example: When the price of corn rises due to increased demand for ethanol, farmers plant more corn, increasing quantity supplied. When hotel prices drop during off-season, hotels take rooms offline or reduce staff, decreasing quantity supplied.

image.caption: Figure 2.2.6: The law of supply: price up, quantity supplied up.

principles.principle: Distinguish Between Change in Supply and Change in Quantity Supplied
principles.statement: Just as with demand, it's crucial to distinguish between a change in supply and a change in quantity supplied. A change in quantity supplied is a movement along a fixed supply curve, caused ONLY by a change in the price of the good itself. A change in supply is a shift of the entire supply curve, caused by a change in any other factor affecting supply—input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, or taxes/subsidies. When the curve shifts, producers offer different amounts at every price. This distinction is essential for correctly analyzing market events. In graphs, movements along are shown as arrows following the curve; shifts are shown as the curve moving to a new position.
principles.application: When analyzing a market event, first identify whether price changed (causing movement) or something else changed (causing shift). For example, 'price of oil increased' affects quantity supplied of oil (movement). 'New drilling technology developed' affects supply of oil (shift).
principles.example: If the price of wheat rises, we move along the wheat supply curve—quantity supplied increases. If a new drought-resistant seed is developed, the entire wheat supply curve shifts right—more supplied at every price.

image.alt: Two graphs: one showing movement along supply curve, one showing shift of entire curve
image.caption: Figure 2.2.7: Change in quantity supplied (movement) vs. change in supply (shift).

principles.principle: Supply Curves Slope Upward Due to Increasing Marginal Cost
principles.statement: The upward slope of supply curves reflects increasing marginal cost. As firms produce more output, they typically face rising costs per unit. This occurs because: (1) In the short run, diminishing returns mean that adding more variable inputs (like labor) to fixed inputs (like factories) eventually yields smaller increases in output, raising cost per unit. (2) Firms may need to use less efficient resources as they expand—the best land, workers, and machines are used first; expanding requires using resources that are less productive. (3) In the long run, industry expansion may bid up input prices, increasing costs for all firms. For these reasons, higher prices are needed to induce firms to increase quantity supplied. The supply curve's slope reflects these increasing costs. In some cases, supply curves can be vertical (fixed supply, like land) or horizontal (constant costs), but upward slope is typical.
principles.application: Understanding why supply slopes upward helps predict how much quantity will respond to price changes. Steeper supply curves mean quantity supplied is less responsive to price changes; flatter curves mean more responsive.
principles.example: A small bakery can increase bread production by hiring an extra worker, but eventually kitchen space limits output. To produce even more, they'd need a larger kitchen (higher fixed costs), so they'll only expand if prices are high enough to justify the investment.

image.caption: Figure 2.2.8: Supply curves slope upward because marginal cost increases with output.

sections.introduction: How does a market actually determine the price you pay? In a free market, the price is not set by any single person or institution. Instead, it emerges from the interaction of buyers and sellers. The equilibrium price—the price that clears the market—is where the plans of consumers and producers align. At this price, the quantity consumers want to buy exactly equals the quantity producers want to sell. In this section, we'll explore how to find equilibrium using tables and graphs, why equilibrium is stable, and what equilibrium tells us about market outcomes.

introduction_image.alt: Balance scale with consumers on one side and producers on the other, balanced at equilibrium
introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.3.1: Market equilibrium balances the plans of buyers and sellers.

key_concept.definition: Market equilibrium occurs at the price where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied. At this price, there is neither a shortage nor a surplus—the market clears. (1) Equilibrium price (market-clearing price): The price at which Qd = Qs. (2) Equilibrium quantity: The quantity bought and sold at the equilibrium price. (3) Finding equilibrium: Using a demand schedule and supply schedule, find the price where quantities match. Graphically, it's the intersection of demand and supply curves. (4) Properties: At equilibrium, all buyers who want to buy at that price can find sellers, and all sellers who want to sell at that price can find buyers. There is no pressure for price to change unless underlying conditions change. (5) Adjustment: If price is above equilibrium, surplus (excess supply) pushes price down. If price is below equilibrium, shortage (excess demand) pushes price up. This self-correcting mechanism is fundamental to market economies. (6) Mathematical approach: With linear demand Qd = a - bP and supply Qs = c + dP, set Qd = Qs and solve for P, then substitute to find Q.
key_concept.context: The concept of equilibrium comes from physics and was applied to economics by Léon Walras and Alfred Marshall. Marshall's supply and demand diagram remains the standard way to present equilibrium. Understanding equilibrium is essential for analyzing how markets allocate resources and how they respond to changes. In AP Microeconomics, equilibrium analysis is the foundation for studying price controls, taxes, subsidies, and market shocks.

image.alt: Supply and demand curves intersecting at equilibrium point E, with equilibrium price and quantity labeled
image.caption: Figure 2.3.2: Market equilibrium occurs where supply and demand curves intersect.

If no exact match exists, equilibrium lies between prices where Qd crosses from above to below Qs. This method is straightforward and helps build intuition before moving to graphs. The equilibrium price is where the market clears. At lower prices, Qd > Qs (shortage); at higher prices, Qs > Qd (surplus). Examining tables helps understand why prices tend toward equilibrium: at prices with shortages, buyers bid prices up; at prices with surpluses, sellers cut prices.

From this point, drop down to the quantity axis to find equilibrium quantity, and across to the price axis to find equilibrium price. Graphs provide an intuitive visual of market outcomes and make it easy to see how shifts affect equilibrium. They also show consumer surplus (area below demand and above price) and producer surplus (area above supply and below price), which are important for welfare analysis. Reading graphs accurately requires careful attention to axes and scales.

classifications.behavior: When demand and supply are given as linear equations, equilibrium can be found algebraically. Given Qd = a - bP and Qs = c + dP (where a,b,c,d are positive numbers), set a - bP = c + dP, solve for P, then substitute back to find Q. This method yields exact values and is useful for quantitative problems. It also allows sensitivity analysis—seeing how changes in parameters affect equilibrium. Understanding the algebraic approach is essential for more advanced economic analysis and for checking graphical solutions.

principles.principle: Equilibrium Is Where Buyers' and Sellers' Plans Align
principles.statement: At the equilibrium price, the quantity consumers want to buy exactly equals the quantity producers want to sell. This alignment means that everyone who wants to buy at that price can find a seller, and everyone who wants to sell at that price can find a buyer. No one is frustrated—there's no line of disappointed buyers (shortage) and no pile of unsold goods (surplus). This coordination happens automatically through price adjustments in free markets. The equilibrium outcome is efficient in the sense that all mutually beneficial transactions occur—any unit where someone values it more than it costs to produce gets produced and sold. Understanding this alignment helps explain why markets are powerful coordination mechanisms.
principles.application: When analyzing a market, always identify the equilibrium first. It's the baseline from which changes are measured. Compare actual prices to equilibrium to predict whether shortages or surpluses exist.
principles.example: In the housing market, equilibrium rent aligns the number of apartments landlords want to rent with the number of apartments renters want to occupy. If rent is above equilibrium, vacancies appear (surplus); if below, waiting lists appear (shortage).

image.alt: Two arrows (buyers and sellers) meeting at equilibrium point
image.caption: Figure 2.3.6: Equilibrium aligns the plans of buyers and sellers.

principles.principle: Markets Tend to Self-Correct Toward Equilibrium
principles.statement: Markets have a natural tendency to move toward equilibrium. If price is above equilibrium, quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded, creating a surplus. Sellers find themselves with unsold inventory and compete for customers by lowering prices. As price falls, quantity demanded increases and quantity supplied decreases, reducing the surplus until equilibrium is reached. If price is below equilibrium, quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied, creating a shortage. Buyers compete for limited goods by bidding prices up. As price rises, quantity demanded decreases and quantity supplied increases, reducing the shortage. This self-correcting mechanism operates without any central direction—it's the invisible hand at work. The speed of adjustment depends on the market—some adjust quickly (financial markets), others slowly (housing markets).
principles.application: When you observe a price that seems 'too high' or 'too low,' expect market forces to push it toward equilibrium unless something prevents adjustment (like price controls). Use surplus/shortage analysis to predict price direction.
principles.example: After a good harvest, farmers bring more corn to market, creating a temporary surplus. Prices fall, encouraging consumers to buy more (corn on sale!) and farmers to plant less next season, moving toward equilibrium.

image.alt: Diagram showing surplus pushing price down, shortage pushing price up, both toward equilibrium
image.caption: Figure 2.3.7: Markets self-correct—surpluses push prices down, shortages push prices up.

principles.principle: Equilibrium Changes When Supply or Demand Shifts
principles.statement: Equilibrium is not fixed—it changes when underlying conditions shift supply or demand. An increase in demand (shift right) raises both equilibrium price and quantity. A decrease in demand (shift left) lowers both. An increase in supply (shift right) lowers equilibrium price and raises quantity. A decrease in supply (shift left) raises equilibrium price and lowers quantity. When both curves shift simultaneously, the effect on price or quantity may be ambiguous, depending on the direction and magnitude of shifts. Understanding these patterns allows economists to predict how events like income changes, technological progress, or natural disasters will affect market outcomes.
principles.application: When analyzing a market change, first determine whether supply shifts, demand shifts, or both. Then apply the rules: D↑ → P↑ Q↑; D↓ → P↓ Q↓; S↑ → P↓ Q↑; S↓ → P↑ Q↓. For simultaneous shifts, consider relative magnitudes.
principles.example: If a new study shows coffee is healthy (demand ↑) and a frost damages coffee crops (supply ↓), price definitely rises, but quantity change is ambiguous—it depends on which shift is larger.

sections.introduction: What happens when a market is not in equilibrium? Sometimes prices are temporarily out of balance; other times, government policies like price ceilings and price floors prevent prices from reaching equilibrium. In these situations, we observe shortages or surpluses that persist, leading to queues, black markets, or unsold goods. Understanding disequilibrium helps explain many real-world phenomena—from rent-controlled apartments with waiting lists to agricultural price supports creating government stockpiles. In this section, we'll explore shortages and surpluses, how markets naturally adjust toward equilibrium, and what happens when prices are prevented from adjusting.

introduction_image.alt: Long line of customers outside a store (shortage) and farmers with unsold crops (surplus)
introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.4.1: Disequilibrium creates shortages (long lines) or surpluses (unsold goods).

key_concept.definition: Disequilibrium occurs when quantity demanded does not equal quantity supplied at the current price. This creates either a shortage or a surplus. (1) Shortage (excess demand): Occurs when price is below equilibrium. Qd > Qs. Some buyers cannot find the good. Characteristics: long lines, waiting lists, black markets, non-price rationing (first-come, first-served, seller preferences). (2) Surplus (excess supply): Occurs when price is above equilibrium. Qs > Qd. Sellers cannot sell all they produce. Characteristics: unsold inventory, price cutting, reduced production, layoffs. (3) Market adjustment: In free markets, shortages push prices up, surpluses push prices down, moving toward equilibrium. (4) Price controls: Government-imposed maximum prices (price ceilings) or minimum prices (price floors) can prevent adjustment to equilibrium, causing persistent shortages or surpluses. (5) Price ceiling: A legal maximum price. If set below equilibrium, creates persistent shortage. Examples: rent control, price controls on gasoline. Consequences: reduced quantity supplied, increased quantity demanded, shortage, non-price rationing, black markets, reduced quality. (6) Price floor: A legal minimum price. If set above equilibrium, creates persistent surplus. Examples: minimum wage, agricultural price supports. Consequences: increased quantity supplied, reduced quantity demanded, surplus, government may need to buy excess, waste, inefficiency.
key_concept.context: Disequilibrium analysis became particularly important during the 1970s when price controls were common, and during agricultural policy debates. The concepts of shortages and surpluses are intuitive but have subtle implications for efficiency and equity. Price controls often create unintended consequences—helping some but hurting others, and always creating inefficiency. Understanding disequilibrium helps evaluate policies and predict their side effects.

image.alt: Supply and demand graph showing shortage (gap where Qd > Qs at low price) and surplus (gap where Qs > Qd at high price)
image.caption: Figure 2.4.2: Shortage occurs below equilibrium; surplus above equilibrium.

classifications.behavior: A shortage occurs when price is too low, causing consumers to want more than producers are willing to supply. In a free market, the shortage would be temporary—prices would rise, eliminating it. But if prices are prevented from rising (by price ceiling or sticky prices), the shortage persists. Persistent shortages lead to non-price rationing: who gets the limited goods? Methods include first-come, first-served (lines); seller preferences (discrimination); coupons or rationing systems; or black markets where goods sell at illegal higher prices. Shortages also reduce quality as sellers have no incentive to maintain standards when goods are scarce. The economic inefficiency is that some buyers who value the good more than its cost cannot get it, while others who value it less (but got in line first) do get it.

image.alt: Graph showing shortage area between demand and supply below equilibrium price
image.caption: Figure 2.4.3: Shortage occurs when price is below equilibrium—Qd exceeds Qs.

examples.explanation: In cities with rent control (price ceiling on apartments), below-equilibrium rents create housing shortages. Waiting lists, lotteries, and discrimination by landlords replace price rationing. Some people can't find apartments despite willingness to pay.
U.S. price controls on gasoline in the 1970s created long lines at gas stations. Drivers waited hours for fuel because price was below equilibrium, preventing market from clearing.

classifications.behavior: A surplus occurs when price is too high, causing producers to supply more than consumers are willing to buy. In free markets, surpluses are temporary—prices fall, eliminating them. But if prices are prevented from falling (by price floor or sticky prices), the surplus persists. Persistent surpluses lead to unsold goods, inventory accumulation, and pressure to cut production and lay off workers. For agricultural price supports, governments often buy the surplus to maintain prices, leading to stockpiles (butter mountains, wine lakes) and waste. Surpluses are inefficient because resources are used to produce goods that people don't value enough to buy at the supported price. The goods may eventually be destroyed, sold at a loss, or given away.

image.alt: Graph showing surplus area between supply and demand above equilibrium price
image.caption: Figure 2.4.4: Surplus occurs when price is above equilibrium—Qs exceeds Qd.

examples.explanation: The U.S. and EU have historically supported farm prices above equilibrium. This creates surpluses of crops like wheat and dairy, which governments sometimes buy and store, leading to massive stockpiles.
A minimum wage above equilibrium creates a surplus of labor—unemployment. More workers want jobs at the higher wage than firms want to hire, leading to job seekers unable to find work.

classifications.behavior: A price ceiling is a legal maximum price that can be charged. To be binding (affect the market), it must be set below the equilibrium price. Binding price ceilings create persistent shortages because price cannot rise to eliminate excess demand. Consequences include: (1) Reduced quantity supplied: producers supply less at the lower price. (2) Increased quantity demanded: consumers want more at the lower price. (3) Shortage: the gap between Qd and Qs. (4) Non-price rationing: goods must be allocated by something other than price—lines, lotteries, seller preferences. (5) Black markets: illegal sales at prices above the ceiling. (6) Reduced quality: sellers cut quality since they can't raise price. (7) Discrimination: sellers may favor friends, family, or those who pay bribes. Price ceilings are often intended to help consumers, but they typically harm those they intend to help by creating shortages and reducing quality.

image.alt: Graph with price ceiling below equilibrium, showing shortage
image.caption: Figure 2.4.5: A binding price ceiling below equilibrium creates persistent shortage.

examples.explanation: New York City's rent control laws keep rents below market for some apartments. Benefits sitting tenants but reduces supply of rental housing and creates shortages—waiting lists, discrimination, and deterioration of controlled units.

Some countries cap prices of life-saving drugs. While intended to make them affordable, this can create shortages as manufacturers supply less, and patients can't find medicines despite willingness to pay.

classifications.behavior: A price floor is a legal minimum price that can be charged. To be binding, it must be set above the equilibrium price. Binding price floors create persistent surpluses because price cannot fall to eliminate excess supply. Consequences include: (1) Increased quantity supplied: producers supply more at the higher price. (2) Reduced quantity demanded: consumers want less at the higher price. (3) Surplus: the gap between Qs and Qd. (4) Unsold goods: producers can't sell all they produce. (5) Government intervention: to maintain the floor, government may buy the surplus, subsidize exports, or pay producers not to produce. (6) Waste: surplus goods may be stored (costly) or destroyed. (7) Inefficiency: resources used to produce goods no one wants at that price. Price floors are often intended to help producers but create surpluses and waste, and consumers pay higher prices.

image.alt: Graph with price floor above equilibrium, showing surplus
image.caption: Figure 2.4.6: A binding price floor above equilibrium creates persistent surplus.

examples.explanation: A minimum wage above the market-clearing wage creates unemployment (surplus of labor). More workers seek jobs than firms want to hire at that wage.
The U.S. government has historically set minimum prices for crops like corn and wheat. This creates surpluses, which the government buys and stores, costing taxpayers and creating inefficiency.

principles.principle: Shortages and Surpluses Create Pressure for Price Adjustment
principles.statement: In free markets, shortages and surpluses are temporary because they create incentives for price adjustment. A shortage means buyers can't get as much as they want—they bid against each other, pushing prices up. Higher prices reduce quantity demanded and increase quantity supplied, eliminating the shortage. A surplus means sellers can't sell all they have—they cut prices to attract more buyers. Lower prices increase quantity demanded and decrease quantity supplied, eliminating the surplus. This self-correcting mechanism is why markets tend toward equilibrium. The speed of adjustment depends on market conditions—flexible prices adjust quickly; sticky prices (like wages or menu costs) adjust more slowly. But the tendency is always toward equilibrium unless prevented.
principles.application: When you observe a shortage or surplus, predict that prices will adjust unless something blocks them. Shortage → price up. Surplus → price down. This helps forecast market direction.
principles.example: When a new video game is released, initial shortage may lead to scalpers selling at high prices (price adjustment). When a fashion trend fades, stores have surplus and put items on sale (price down).

image.alt: Shortage with upward arrow, surplus with downward arrow, both pointing to equilibrium
image.caption: Figure 2.4.7: Shortages push prices up; surpluses push prices down.

principles.principle: Price Ceilings Create Shortages and Non-Price Rationing
principles.statement: When government imposes a price ceiling below equilibrium, it prevents the market from reaching equilibrium. The resulting persistent shortage must be rationed by some method other than price. Common non-price rationing mechanisms include: (1) First-come, first-served: lines and waiting lists. (2) Seller preferences: landlords may discriminate by race, gender, or family status. (3) Coupons or rationing tickets: government issues rights to buy. (4) Black markets: illegal sales at higher prices. These methods are generally less efficient than price rationing because goods don't necessarily go to those who value them most, but to those with time to wait, connections to sellers, or luck. Price ceilings also reduce quality and investment because sellers can't earn normal returns. While intended to help consumers, price ceilings often harm the very people they're meant to help by creating shortages and reducing quality.
principles.application: When evaluating a proposed price ceiling, consider: Will it be below equilibrium? Who will get the goods instead of price? What are the unintended consequences (black markets, quality deterioration)?
principles.example: Venezuela's price controls on basic foods created massive shortages despite the intent to make food affordable. People spent hours in lines, and black markets flourished at much higher prices.

image.alt: Price ceiling graph with shortage, plus icons for lines, black markets, quality decline
image.caption: Figure 2.4.8: Price ceilings cause shortages and lead to non-price rationing.

principles.principle: Price Floors Create Surpluses and Waste
principles.statement: When government imposes a price floor above equilibrium, it creates a persistent surplus. For goods, this means unsold inventory. For labor (minimum wage), this means unemployment. To maintain the floor, government often must intervene further—buying surplus agricultural products, paying farmers not to plant, or subsidizing exports. These interventions are costly and create waste: surplus goods may spoil in storage or be destroyed while people elsewhere go hungry. Price floors also lead to inefficient allocation: resources are used to produce goods that consumers don't value enough to buy at the floor price. While intended to help producers (or workers), price floors create surpluses, waste, and higher prices for consumers, and may not even help the intended beneficiaries (e.g., minimum wage may help some workers but price others out of jobs).
principles.application: When evaluating a proposed price floor, consider: Will it be above equilibrium? What will happen to the surplus? Will government need to buy it? Who bears the cost?
principles.example: EU agricultural price supports created 'wine lakes' and 'butter mountains'—vast stockpiles of surplus goods that cost taxpayers billions and were sometimes destroyed while poor countries faced food shortages.

image.alt: Price floor graph with surplus, plus icons for unsold goods, government buying, waste
image.caption: Figure 2.4.9: Price floors create surpluses and often lead to government purchases and waste.

principles.statement: Both price ceilings and price floors create deadweight loss—a measure of economic inefficiency representing mutually beneficial transactions that no longer occur. With a price ceiling below equilibrium, some transactions that would have occurred (where value to buyers exceeded cost to sellers) don't happen because quantity supplied is too low. With a price floor above equilibrium, some transactions don't happen because quantity demanded is too low. Deadweight loss measures the value of these foregone transactions—the loss to society from interference with market outcomes. This is why economists generally oppose price controls except in specific circumstances (like emergencies) where equity concerns may outweigh efficiency losses. Understanding deadweight loss is essential for evaluating the full cost of price controls.
principles.application: When analyzing price controls, calculate or estimate deadweight loss. It represents the harm to society beyond the redistribution between buyers and sellers. Policies that create large deadweight losses are generally inefficient.
principles.example: A rent control law may transfer wealth from landlords to some tenants, but it also creates deadweight loss because fewer apartments are supplied and some people who would have rented can't find apartments at all.

image.alt: Supply and demand graph with price ceiling showing deadweight loss triangle

worked_examples.title: Analyzing a Price Ceiling

image.alt: Apartment rental market data
image.caption: Figure 2.4.11: Analyze effects of rent control price ceiling.

worked_examples.problem:
The apartment market in a city has demand Qd = 1000 - 2P and supply Qs = 200 + 2P, where P is monthly rent in dollars, Q is number of apartments. The government imposes a rent ceiling of $150 per month.
a) Find equilibrium price and quantity without rent control.
b) Is the price ceiling binding?
c) What is quantity demanded at the ceiling? Quantity supplied?
d) What is the shortage of apartments?
e) What problems will likely arise?

step_by_step.explanation: Equilibrium price is $200. Ceiling is $150, which is below equilibrium. So the ceiling is binding.
Shortage = Qd - Qs = 700 - 500 = 200 apartments.

Likely problems: long waiting lists, discrimination by landlords, black markets (illegal payments to get apartments), reduced quality and maintenance of existing apartments, reduced construction of new apartments.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) P=$200, Q=600. b) Yes, binding. c) Qd=700, Qs=500. d) Shortage of 200. e) Waiting lists, discrimination, black markets, quality decline.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Binding price ceilings create persistent shortages and various unintended consequences.

worked_examples.title: Analyzing a Price Floor

image.alt: Agricultural market data
image.caption: Figure 2.4.12: Analyze effects of agricultural price support floor.

worked_examples.problem:
The wheat market has demand Qd = 500 - 10P and supply Qs = 100 + 10P, where P is price per bushel, Q is millions of bushels. The government sets a price floor of $25 per bushel and agrees to buy any surplus.
a) Find equilibrium price and quantity.
b) Is the price floor binding?
c) What is quantity demanded at the floor? Quantity supplied?
d) What is the surplus? How much will the government need to buy?
e) What is the cost to the government if it pays the floor price for surplus?
f) What are the efficiency implications?

step_by_step.explanation: Equilibrium price is $20. Floor is $25, which is above equilibrium. So the floor is binding.
Surplus = Qs - Qd = 350 - 250 = 100 million bushels. Government must buy this surplus to maintain the floor price.
Cost = surplus × floor price = 100 million × $25 = $2.5 billion.

Resources are used to produce 100 million bushels that consumers don't want at that price. This is inefficient. Taxpayers bear $2.5 billion cost. Some of the surplus may spoil or be wasted. The policy transfers money from taxpayers to farmers.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) P=$20, Q=300. b) Yes, binding. c) Qd=250, Qs=350. d) Surplus=100 million, government buys that. e) $2.5 billion. f) Inefficient resource use, taxpayer cost, potential waste.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Binding price floors create surpluses that often require government purchases, costing taxpayers and creating inefficiency.

image.alt: Market data table
image.caption: Figure 2.4.13: Calculate shortage or surplus at different prices.

worked_examples.problem:
A market has the following demand and supply schedule:
Price: $4, $5, $6, $7, $8
Qd: 500, 450, 400, 350, 300
Qs: 200, 300, 400, 500, 600
a) What is equilibrium price and quantity?
b) At a price of $5, is there shortage or surplus? How much?
c) At a price of $7, is there shortage or surplus? How much?
d) If the government sets a price floor at $7, what happens?
e) If the government sets a price ceiling at $5, what happens?

step_by_step.explanation: At $6, Qd = 400 and Qs = 400. Equilibrium price = $6, quantity = 400.
Qd = 450, Qs = 300. Qd > Qs by 150, so shortage of 150 units.
Qd = 350, Qs = 500. Qs > Qd by 150, so surplus of 150 units.
$7 is above equilibrium, so binding floor. Creates surplus of 150. Without government action, price would tend to fall, but floor prevents it. Unsold goods accumulate.
$5 is below equilibrium, so binding ceiling. Creates shortage of 150. Without ceiling, price would rise, but prevented. Non-price rationing needed.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) $6, 400. b) Shortage 150. c) Surplus 150. d) Surplus of 150, unsold goods. e) Shortage of 150, non-price rationing.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Prices below equilibrium cause shortages; above cause surpluses. Price controls prevent adjustment and create persistent imbalances.

sections.introduction: Markets are constantly changing. Incomes rise, technology improves, weather affects crops, and consumer tastes evolve. Each of these changes shifts either the demand curve or the supply curve, leading to a new equilibrium. Understanding how to analyze these changes—predicting the direction of price and quantity adjustments—is a essential skill in microeconomics. In this section, we'll develop a systematic approach to analyzing market changes, considering single shifts and simultaneous shifts, and learning to handle ambiguous cases.

introduction_image.alt: Before and after graphs showing shifting curves and new equilibria
introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.5.1: Market changes shift curves and create new equilibria.

key_concept.definition: Analyzing market changes involves predicting how equilibrium price and quantity respond to shifts in supply or demand. (1) Single shift rules: (a) Demand increase (shift right): Price ↑, Quantity ↑. (b) Demand decrease (shift left): Price ↓, Quantity ↓. (c) Supply increase (shift right): Price ↓, Quantity ↑. (d) Supply decrease (shift left): Price ↑, Quantity ↓. (2) Simultaneous shifts: When both curves shift, one outcome (price or quantity) may be ambiguous, depending on the relative magnitudes of the shifts. (3) Step-by-step approach: (a) Identify which curve(s) shift and direction. (b) Determine effect on equilibrium using graph. (c) For simultaneous shifts, consider whether effects on price or quantity reinforce or oppose. (d) If opposing, the net effect depends on which shift dominates. (4) Common shifters review: Demand shifters—income, prices of related goods, tastes, expectations, number of buyers. Supply shifters—input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, taxes/subsidies, natural conditions. (5) Comparative statics: The method of comparing old and new equilibrium after a change.
key_concept.context: Analyzing market changes is the heart of applied microeconomics. It's how economists predict the effects of events—a new tax, a technological breakthrough, a change in consumer preferences. This analysis appears throughout the AP curriculum and is essential for understanding real-world markets. Mastering the systematic approach will serve you well in exams and in interpreting economic news.

image.caption: Figure 2.5.2: Summary of how single shifts affect equilibrium price and quantity.

classifications.value: Change in demand with supply constant
characteristics: P and Q move same direction
classifications.behavior: When only demand changes, both equilibrium price and quantity move in the same direction as the demand shift. An increase in demand (right shift) raises both price and quantity. A decrease in demand (left shift) lowers both. This is because the supply curve is upward-sloping—higher demand means buyers compete for goods, pushing up price, and producers respond by supplying more along their supply curve. The magnitude of changes depends on the slopes of the curves (elasticities), but the direction is unambiguous. This pattern holds for any demand shifter: income increases (normal goods), price of substitutes increases, price of complements decreases, favorable taste changes, population growth, or expectations of future price increases.

image.alt: Two graphs: demand increase (right) with P↑ Q↑, demand decrease (left) with P↓ Q↓
image.caption: Figure 2.5.3: Demand shifts cause P and Q to move in same direction.

examples.process: Health study increases demand for blueberries
examples.explanation: News that blueberries improve health shifts demand right. Price rises, quantity rises as farmers supply more along their supply curve.
Income falls (normal good), demand shifts left. Price falls, quantity falls as manufacturers reduce production.

classifications.value: Change in supply with demand constant
characteristics: P and Q move opposite directions
classifications.behavior: When only supply changes, price and quantity move in opposite directions. An increase in supply (right shift) lowers price and increases quantity. A decrease in supply (left shift) raises price and decreases quantity. This is because the demand curve is downward-sloping—more supply means sellers compete for buyers, pushing price down, and buyers respond by purchasing more along their demand curve. The direction is unambiguous, though magnitude varies. This pattern holds for any supply shifter: lower input prices, technological progress, more sellers, favorable natural conditions, subsidies, or expectations of lower future prices (which increase current supply).

image.alt: Two graphs: supply increase (right) with P↓ Q↑, supply decrease (left) with P↑ Q↓
image.caption: Figure 2.5.4: Supply shifts cause P and Q to move in opposite directions.

examples.process: New technology reduces solar panel costs
examples.explanation: Supply shifts right. Price of solar panels falls, quantity installed increases.
Supply shifts left. Price of oranges rises, quantity sold falls.

classifications.value: Both supply and demand change at once
characteristics: Can determine one direction if shifts reinforce
classifications.behavior: When both supply and demand shift simultaneously, the effect on either price or quantity may be ambiguous, depending on the direction and magnitude of the shifts. Four cases: (1) Demand ↑ and Supply ↑: Quantity definitely increases (both increase Q). Price ambiguous—demand ↑ pushes price up, supply ↑ pushes price down. Net effect depends on which shift is larger. (2) Demand ↑ and Supply ↓: Price definitely increases (both push price up). Quantity ambiguous—demand ↑ pushes Q up, supply ↓ pushes Q down. (3) Demand ↓ and Supply ↑: Price definitely decreases (both push price down). Quantity ambiguous—demand ↓ pushes Q down, supply ↑ pushes Q up. (4) Demand ↓ and Supply ↓: Quantity definitely decreases (both push Q down). Price ambiguous—demand ↓ pushes price down, supply ↓ pushes price up. To determine ambiguous outcomes, you need information about the relative sizes of the shifts or the elasticities of the curves. This analysis is crucial for real-world situations where multiple factors change simultaneously.

image.caption: Figure 2.5.5: Simultaneous shifts can make price or quantity ambiguous.

examples.process: Smartphone market: technology improves (S↑) and incomes rise (D↑)
examples.explanation: Quantity definitely increases. Price ambiguous—technology pushes price down, income pushes price up. Actual outcome depends on which effect dominates. In reality, smartphone prices have often fallen while quality improved.

examples.process: Housing market in growing city: population increases (D↑) and construction costs rise (S↓)
examples.explanation: Price definitely increases. Quantity ambiguous—more people want housing (Q↑) but higher costs reduce construction (Q↓). Actual quantity change depends on relative strengths.

principles.principle: Systematic Approach: Determine Which Curves Shift and How
principles.statement: To analyze any market change, follow a systematic process: (1) Identify the event and which curve(s) it affects. Is it a demand shifter (income, related goods prices, tastes, expectations, number of buyers) or a supply shifter (input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, taxes, natural conditions)? (2) Determine the direction of the shift (right for increase, left for decrease). (3) Draw or visualize the shift and find the new equilibrium. (4) Compare new equilibrium to old to determine changes in price and quantity. (5) If both curves shift, determine which effects on price and quantity reinforce or oppose. For opposing effects, note ambiguity. This systematic approach prevents errors and provides a clear framework for answering exam questions and real-world analysis.
principles.application: When given a market scenario, always ask: Which curve shifts? Which direction? Then apply the rules. Write out your reasoning step by step. For ambiguous cases, explain that the outcome depends on relative magnitudes.
principles.example: Event: 'A drought reduces wheat harvest, and simultaneously, a new health study praises wheat's benefits.' Drought affects supply (left shift). Health study affects demand (right shift). Price definitely rises (both push price up). Quantity ambiguous—drought reduces Q, health study increases Q. Need more info to determine quantity direction.

image.caption: Figure 2.5.6: Systematic approach to analyzing market changes.

principles.statement: Graphs are powerful tools for analyzing market changes. Drawing supply and demand diagrams helps visualize shifts and see the effects on price and quantity. Even a quick sketch can clarify whether price rises or falls, and whether quantity increases or decreases. For simultaneous shifts, graphs make it clear why one outcome is ambiguous—you can see the two opposing forces. When practicing, draw the original equilibrium, then draw the new curve(s) with arrows showing shifts. Label old and new equilibrium points. This visual approach reinforces understanding and is essential for exam success (many AP questions include graphs or require you to draw them).
principles.application: On exams and in practice, always sketch a graph when analyzing market changes. Label axes, original curves, shift directions, and new equilibrium. This makes your reasoning clear and helps catch errors.
principles.example: For an increase in demand, draw original D and S, then D2 to the right. New intersection is higher price and higher quantity. For simultaneous shifts, draw both new curves and note the range of possible new equilibria.

image.caption: Figure 2.5.7: Use graphs to visualize and analyze market changes.

principles.principle: When Both Curves Shift, One Outcome Is Ambiguous
principles.statement: A common exam question involves simultaneous shifts. The key insight is that when both curves shift in directions that have opposing effects on either price or quantity, that variable becomes ambiguous—it could increase, decrease, or stay the same depending on the relative sizes of the shifts. For example, if demand increases (pushes price up) and supply increases (pushes price down), the net effect on price is ambiguous. To determine the actual outcome, you need additional information: which shift was larger? how elastic are the curves? In multiple-choice questions, the correct answer often is 'price may increase, decrease, or stay the same' or 'quantity definitely increases but price is ambiguous.' Understanding which outcomes are determinate and which are ambiguous is crucial for correct analysis.
principles.application: When analyzing simultaneous shifts, first determine which variable (P or Q) has reinforcing effects—that one is determinate. The other variable, with opposing effects, is ambiguous. State clearly that it depends on the relative magnitudes of the shifts.
principles.example: Demand increases (P↑ Q↑) and supply decreases (P↑ Q↓). Price effects reinforce (both up) so P definitely rises. Quantity effects oppose, so Q is ambiguous. Without knowing which shift dominates, we cannot say whether Q rises or falls.

image.caption: Figure 2.5.8: With simultaneous shifts, one outcome is determinate, the other ambiguous.

worked_examples.problem:
For each event, determine the effect on equilibrium price and quantity in the specified market:
a) Coffee market: Price of tea increases sharply.
b) New car market: Automobile workers' wages increase.
c) Air travel market: Fuel prices decrease.
d) Movie tickets market: Streaming services become more popular.
e) Housing market: Population of the city increases.

step_by_step.explanation: Tea is a substitute for coffee. Tea price ↑ increases demand for coffee (shift right). Supply unchanged. Result: P ↑, Q ↑.
Wages are an input price increase. This decreases supply of cars (shift left). Demand unchanged. Result: P ↑, Q ↓.
Fuel is an input for air travel. Fuel price ↓ decreases costs, increasing supply (shift right). Demand unchanged. Result: P ↓, Q ↑.
Streaming is a substitute for movies. Increased popularity reduces demand for movie tickets (shift left). Supply unchanged. Result: P ↓, Q ↓.
Population increase means more buyers, increasing demand for housing (shift right). Supply unchanged (in short run). Result: P ↑, Q ↑.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) P↑ Q↑. b) P↑ Q↓. c) P↓ Q↑. d) P↓ Q↓. e) P↑ Q↑.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Single shifts have predictable effects: D shifts move P and Q same direction; S shifts move them opposite.

worked_examples.title: Simultaneous Shifts Analysis

image.alt: Events with multiple changes
image.caption: Figure 2.5.10: Analyze simultaneous shift effects.

worked_examples.problem:
For each scenario, determine the effects on equilibrium price and quantity (↑, ↓, or ambiguous):
a) Smartphone market: Technology improves (S↑) and consumer incomes rise (D↑, normal good).
b) Beef market: Price of cattle feed increases (S↓) and price of chicken (substitute) increases (D↑).
c) Apartment market: New construction increases supply (S↑) and population decreases (D↓).
d) Gasoline market: Oil prices rise (S↓) and people buy more fuel-efficient cars (D↓).

step_by_step.explanation: S↑ → P↓ Q↑; D↑ → P↑ Q↑. Q effects reinforce (both ↑), so Q definitely ↑. P effects oppose (↑ and ↓), so P ambiguous.
S↓ → P↑ Q↓; D↑ → P↑ Q↑. P effects reinforce (both ↑), so P definitely ↑. Q effects oppose (↓ and ↑), so Q ambiguous.
S↑ → P↓ Q↑; D↓ → P↓ Q↓. P effects reinforce (both ↓), so P definitely ↓. Q effects oppose (↑ and ↓), so Q ambiguous.
S↓ → P↑ Q↓; D↓ → P↓ Q↓. Q effects reinforce (both ↓), so Q definitely ↓. P effects oppose (↑ and ↓), so P ambiguous.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) P ambiguous, Q↑. b) P↑, Q ambiguous. c) P↓, Q ambiguous. d) P ambiguous, Q↓.
worked_examples.concept_applied: With simultaneous shifts, one variable is determinate (reinforcing effects), the other ambiguous (opposing effects).

summary: Supply and demand are the fundamental tools of microeconomic analysis. The law of demand states that, ceteris paribus, price and quantity demanded are inversely related, shown by a downward-sloping demand curve. Changes in price cause movements along the demand curve; changes in income, prices of related goods, tastes, expectations, or number of buyers shift the entire demand curve. The law of supply states that, ceteris paribus, price and quantity supplied are directly related, shown by an upward-sloping supply curve. Changes in price cause movements along the supply curve; changes in input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, taxes, subsidies, or natural conditions shift the entire supply curve. Market equilibrium occurs where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied, determining the market-clearing price and quantity. At prices below equilibrium, shortages occur, pushing prices up; at prices above equilibrium, surpluses occur, pushing prices down. Price ceilings (legal maximums) set below equilibrium create persistent shortages and non-price rationing; price floors (legal minimums) set above equilibrium create persistent surpluses and often require government purchases. When analyzing market changes, follow a systematic approach: identify events, determine which curves shift and in what direction, and combine effects. Single shifts have unambiguous effects. Simultaneous shifts make one outcome ambiguous—the net effect depends on relative magnitudes. Mastering supply and demand analysis is essential for understanding how markets work and how they respond to changes in economic conditions and government policies.
